title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.10 Part 2 | 15-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya
Chakshurun Meelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatyade Shatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaivanarottamam
Devim Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udhiraye
Namaste
In this session, I'll be continuing from the previous session to describe the different meanings of the Atmarama words,
the same words that we discussed in the last session, the 10th verse of the 7th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam,
the famous Atmarama words.
Just to refresh your memory, the meaning of that verse,
all different varieties of Atmaramas or those who take pleasure in the Atmarama,
the life of the self, especially those engaged in self-realization,
though freed from all kinds of material bondage,
desire to render unalloyed devotional service to the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
This means the Lord possesses transcendental qualities and therefore can attract everyone, including liberated souls.
If you remember, before this, there was a question raised by Saunakarishi to Suta Goswami,
why did Sukadev Goswami, the great devotee of the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
why did Sukadev Goswami, the great devotee of the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
why did Sukadev Goswami, the great devotee of the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
why did Sukadev Goswami, the great devotee of the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
why did Sukadev Goswami, the great devotee of the Supreme Personality of Godhead,
undertake the trouble of going through this vast literature of Bhagavatam from his father Vyasadeva,
when he was already a liberated soul?
So, here Suta Goswami is justifying that even liberated souls are attracted to Krishna
because of his wonderful qualities.
He is a reservoir of unlimited good qualities.
Srila Bhaktivinoda Thakur says,
and who are the varieties of different transcendentalists who get attracted to Krishna?
And even non-transcendentalists get attracted to Krishna.
So, that is described elaborately by Lord Chaitanya to Srila Sanatana Goswami.
So, here continuing the description of the different meanings,
the word guna means quality.
The qualities of Krishna are transcendentally situated
and are unlimited in quantity.
All of the spiritual qualities are full of transcendental bliss.
That is the nature of Krishna's qualities.
Krishna's transcendental qualities of opulence, sweetness and mercy are perfect and full.
As far as Krishna's affections are concerned,
leaning toward his devotees is concerned he's so magnanimous that he can give

in return for the service they render to Krishna so Krishna says I have nothing
in my possession which I can give you so I give myself to you there is such a
statement in these scriptures Krishna offers himself to his devotees because

Kumaras, Sanaka, Sanatana, Sanandana and Sanat Kumara were attracted to the lotus feet of Krishna by the aroma of the Tursi that had been offered to the Lord.
Lord Vishnu or Narayana always is worshipped by offering Tursi mixed with Chandan. We call it Charan Tursi.
So that is offered to Lord Narayana or Krishna or Vishnu always by the devotees.
So the fragrance of that Tursi mixed with Chandan attracted the attention of the people.
These are the four liberated sages, Kumaras.
So that is explained further.
In the Bhagavatam, there is a statement.
When the breeze carrying the aroma of Tursi leaves and saffron from the lotus feet of the lotus eyed personality of Godhead entered through the nostrils into the hearts of those sages, the Kumaras.
They experienced a change in both body and mind.
Even though they were attached to the inner world.
Even though they were attached to the inner world.
This was Murabbi's impassional Brahman understanding.
There is a description in the 3ивается 15th chapter of Deshrinmad Bhagavatam
That once these four Kumaras happened to be wandering
without any particular aim because they were liberated sages.
They do not have any attraction for anything material in this world.
They are not interested in any material enjoyment.
Material power.
material facilities material opulence they are not interested in any of those things

Swami's mind was carried away by hearing the pastimes of the Lord. So, it is said Shukadeva
Goswami also was situated in impersonal understanding of the absolute truth, Brahman
realization. But when he heard the pastimes of the Lord from his father Vyasadeva, when Vyasadeva
compiled and was revising the Srimad Bhagavatam under the instruction of Narada, that is when
Shukadeva Goswami got attracted to the personality of Godhead Krishna. So, Shukadeva Goswami's own
words, it is described, Shukadeva Goswami is addressing Pariksit Maharaj, my dear king,
although I was fully situated in the transcendental position in impersonal Brahman realization,
I was nonetheless attracted to the pastimes of Lord Krishna. Therefore, I studied Srimad Bhagavatam
from my father.
Vyasadeva is a statement by Shukadeva Goswami himself. And Suta Goswami also confirms this
by offering his respectful obeisances to Shukadeva Goswami. Suta Goswami says,
I offer my respectful obeisances unto Srila Shukadeva Goswami, the son of Vyasadeva,
and the destroyer of all sinful reactions. Being full in self-realization and bliss,
he had no material desire. Still,
he was attracted by the transcendental pastimes of the Supreme Personality of Godhead and out of
compassion for the people in general. He described the transcendental historical literature called
Srimad Bhagavatam. This is compared, this Bhagavatam is compared to the light of the
absolute truth. Bhagavatam can enlighten us in the transcendental subject matter of the absolute
truth.
He described the personality of Godhead, Krishna, and his personal qualities, his personal activities,
his personal form, his personal abode, his personal paraphernalia, his personal devotees.
That's what the Bhagavatam is all about. So, this is the way Krishna attracted the four Kumaras.
Krishna attracted the,

the,
Shukadeva Goswami. Both of them were situated in impersonal liberation. Next, Lord Chaitanya
describes, Lord Sri Krishna attracts the minds of all the gopis in Vrindavan with his beautiful
transcendental bodily features. This is a statement by the gopis themselves. They are addressing
Krishna.
Dear Krishna,
We have simply surrendered ourselves as your maidservants. For we have seen your beautiful face decorated with
tresses of hair,
your earrings falling upon your cheeks.
The nectar of your lips and
the beauty of your smile. Indeed because we have been embraced by your arms,
which give us courage and seen your chest, which is beautiful and broad, we have
surrendered ourselves.
The gopis are completely captivated
